Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing for physiological and genetic independence of rapidly evolving lifecycle components in the apple maggot, a model for seasonal adaptation
Award.AbstractNarration: Organisms must time their lifecycles to avoid stressful periods of the year (e.g., winter cold and lack of resources) and to exploit the good times of the year when weather is favorable and resources are abundant. Dormancy responses have evolved in many organisms, from plants and microbes to mammals and insects, to achieve synchrony with local seasonal conditions. Organisms are increasingly challenged by new seasonal regimes caused by 1) contemporary climate change, 2) habitat modifications from human development and urbanization, and 3) movement of species into new areas through managed or accidental introductions. Thus, understanding how dormancy responses rapidly evolve and compensate for shifts in seasonality will be a critical component for understanding the persistence and spread of native and invasive species in our rapidly changing world. This research will characterize the mechanisms that allow rapid adaptation to novel seasonality via changes in dormancy in the apple maggot fly, Rhagoletis pomonella, a major pest of apples and a textbook example of rapid species formation. Within the last 200 years, R. pomonella has shifted from its native host hawthorn (Crataegus mollis) to introduced, domesticated apple (Malus domestica), and in the process has formed new, partially reproductively isolated populations on apples. Seasonal fruiting time differs substantially among plant species in a given region, so adapting to a novel fruit requires adaptation in insect seasonal timing. In R. pomonella, the newly derived apple population has become established on their novel host fruit via evolved differences in timing of the overwintering dormant stage, which results in temporal matching of insect growth and reproduction with earlier seasonal availability of apple compared to hawthorn fruits. Physiological mechanisms that evolve to adjust dormancy timing are poorly understood, and this research will leverage variation among the fly populations to quantify physiological differences in gene and protein expression and differences in the genome that underlie adaptation at key regulatory points across the fly life cycle. Additionally, experiments will address whether common physiological mechanisms underlie adaptation across the three phases of dormancy (dormancy induction, maintenance, and termination) potentially constraining the rate or direction of evolutionary responses to changing seasonality. This fundamental research has implications in numerous contexts from preserving biodiversity to forecasting agricultural production and the spread of invasive species. Beyond identifying important features facilitating rapid responses to seasonal change, the project will also enhance a pre-collegiate education program in evolutionary biology. Host race formation in R. pomonella provides a clear and intuitive example of ecological adaptation and the genesis of new crop pests, making the flies excellent ambassadors for evolution, a subject poorly understood by many students and the general public. The research team previously developed a workshop and outreach program for STEM education to enhance the evolution knowledge of high school teachers and students from Florida and Puerto Rico, providing materials for science curricula. The current grant will expand the high-school teacher training, add freely accessible web-based curricular materials, and most importantly, formally evaluate the impact of the educational program. Survey-based assessments delivered before, during and after the workshop will assess changes in perception of frequently misunderstood concepts in evolutionary biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

 

Many animals, plants, and other life forms enter a dormant state to weather unfavorable conditions, often cold winters, and synchronize growth and reproduction with favorable conditions, often warm summers. The form and annual timing of dormancy shows substantial diversity, reflecting evolutionary adaptations to different environments. Yet in animals, we currently understand very little about how variation in the genetic and physiological architecture developmental and hormonal pathways affect dormancy, though we know that dormancy can evolve rapidly in the face of biological introduction or changing climates. Diapause, a developmentally programmed dormancy in insects, is of particular interest because it can help predict seasonal abundance and is a potential target of control for pest and disease-vectoring insect populations. In this project, we used genetic and physiological methods to test whether and how genetic variants affecting dormancy in the North American apple maggot fly, Rhagoletis pomonella, contribute to natural variation in dormancy that has rapidly evolved in the last 300 years. Rhagoletis pomonella larvae feed on the fruits of native hawthorn trees, but populations have evolved to infest apple trees that are introduced to North America. Despite the fact that apple- and haw-infesting populations (hereafter, ‘host races’) can occur in the same geographic areas, they have become and remain genetically distinct because of evolved differences in several traits, including seasonal timing, in response to strong natural selection. Apple trees generally fruit earlier than hawthorns, and the apple host race has evolved earlier seasonal emergence timing by shortening the duration of pupal diapause, a type of dormancy. Our studies used a combination of transcriptomic, genomic, and physiological approaches to identify genetic variants associated with changes in developmental regulation that result in shorter diapause duration and also clearly contribute to evolutionary differences between the host races. There are many associated genetic variants, conforming to a polygenic model wherein seasonal timing is determined by the allelic state of many genes. Some of these same variants affecting seasonal timing were also associated with the propensity to enter diapause under warm pre-winter conditions, a trait that also experience strong natural selection that differs between haw and apple host races. Patterns of genetic divergence between host races strongly suggested that variants shared between seasonal timing and diapause initiation phenotypes demonstrate antagonistic pleiotropy, wherein a variant causing earlier emergence time may also be associated with low diapause intensity, the ability to remain in diapause despite warm conditions. Selection on the apple host race favors earlier emergence in the spring and more intense diapause in the fall, thus this pleiotropy appears to constrain adaptive evolution. Our transcriptomic and physiological studies elucidate hormonal and developmental pathways such as ecdysone, Wnt, and insulin signaling that appear to follow an accelerated regulatory program coincident with earlier seasonal emergence in apple host race flies. However, whether these same pathways influence pre-winter diapause intensity differences between the two host races remains an outstanding question. Overall, these results suggest a polygenic basis for naturally segregating variation in the pre-winter and post-winter components of insect diapause that controls basic mechanisms of developmental progression and that can evolve rapidly in the face of changing environments.

 

Broader impacts

 

Insects are important players in ecosystem stability and services, including critical roles as beneficial pollinators and biocontrol agents, as well as their more notorious roles as devastating crop pests and vectors of deadly human diseases. Our studies contribute to a growing body of literature that help us to understand and predict how key traits that determine seasonal and geographic population abundance are regulated, and how these important seasonal traits evolve in response to changing habitats and climates. In addition, our projects also provided education for numerous graduate students, undergraduate students, and postdocs. In addition to research training, a major goal of our project was to develop and deploy a curriculum unit targeted towards high school students to fill an important gap in the public’s understanding of evolution by natural selection, the basic principle that adaptation can only occur if there is heritable variation in traits. Working with PIs, collaborators at the U. Florida Center for Precollegiate Education and Training (CPET), and two high school teachers, we developed a curriculum based on Next Generation Science Standards for high school biology/AP biology. The curriculum was publicized in workshops at three conferences: STEM Bugs presentations at the 2016 International Congress of Entomology, the 2017 Entomological Society of America conference, and the 2016 National Association of Biology Teachers conference, as well as through a peer-reviewed publication in the American Biology Teacher. The curriculum was widely distributed and has contributed to high school science education in schools in Florida, Ohio, and other states.
